name: Jumping Jacks
description: Begin standing with feet together and arms at sides. Jump feet outward while raising arms overhead, then jump feet back together as arms return to sides.
formTips: Land softly on balls of feet when jumping out and in
Extend arms fully overhead without locking elbows
Keep jumps low to the ground for better control
Maintain a consistent, controlled rhythm
commonMistakes: Landing heavily or flat-footed
Not extending arms fully overhead
Moving too quickly with poor form
Hunching shoulders toward ears
benefits: Requires no equipment and minimal space
breathingPattern: Find a rhythm with your movement - typically exhale on the outward jump, inhale on the inward jump
preparationSteps: Clear adequate space around you
Stand with feet together
Relax shoulders and arms at sides
Engage core slightly before beginning

name: Jumping Squat
description: A dynamic squat variation where you explosively jump upward from the bottom squat position, landing softly back into a squat to begin the next repetition.
formTips: Lower into a half-squat before jumping
Swing arms up as you jump for momentum
Land softly with knees slightly bent
Control the landing by going directly into the next rep
commonMistakes: Landing with straight legs
Allowing knees to cave inward
Not using arms to help with the movement
Excessive forward lean
benefits: Combines strength and cardio training simultaneously
Builds explosive power in the lower body
breathingPattern: Inhale as you lower, exhale forcefully as you jump
preparationSteps: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart
Position arms in front for balance
Engage core and maintain upright posture
Ensure adequate space above and around you

name: High Knees
description: A running-in-place exercise where you lift knees toward chest in an exaggerated running motion, keeping a quick pace while staying in one spot.
formTips: Drive knees up to hip height or higher
Land lightly on balls of feet
Keep torso upright with slight forward lean
Pump arms in opposition to legs
commonMistakes: Not lifting knees high enough
Landing heavily on feet
Leaning too far forward or backward
Moving too slowly to elevate heart rate
benefits: Improves running form and knee lift
Can be performed in limited space
breathingPattern: Find a rhythm with your movement, typically inhaling for 2-3 knee lifts and exhaling for 2-3 lifts
preparationSteps: Stand with feet hip-width apart
Engage core and maintain good posture
Begin with a slow marching motion to warm up
Gradually increase speed and height of knee lift

name: Mountain Climber
description: Begin in a plank position with hands under shoulders. Rapidly alternate bringing knees toward chest in a running motion while maintaining a stable upper body.
formTips: Keep hips low and in line with shoulders
Drive knees forward with control and speed
Maintain a strong plank position throughout
Keep shoulders stacked over wrists
commonMistakes: Bouncing hips up and down
Not bringing knees far enough forward
Sagging in the lower back
Moving too slowly to elevate heart rate
progressionExercises: mountain climber with cross-body knee drive
benefits: Combines strength training with cardiovascular benefit
Strengthens core while improving hip mobility
Burns calories and increases heart rate efficiently
breathingPattern: Breathe rhythmically with movement; avoid holding breath
preparationSteps: Start in a high plank position with hands directly under shoulders
Set feet hip-width apart
Engage core and establish a stable position
Look slightly ahead to maintain neutral neck alignment

name: Burpee
description: Begin standing, then squat down and place hands on floor, kick feet back to a plank position, perform a push-up, jump feet back to hands, and explosively jump up with arms overhead.
formTips: Maintain a strong core throughout the entire movement
Land softly with knees slightly bent after jumping
Keep shoulders stacked over wrists in plank position
Control your descent in the push-up portion
commonMistakes: Rounding the back during the plank/push-up
Not performing a full range of motion
Landing with straight legs on the jump
Holding breath during the exercise
benefits: Elevates heart rate for maximum cardiovascular conditioning
Burns significant calories in short time periods
breathingPattern: Inhale as you lower to squat, exhale during the push-up, inhale as you jump feet forward, exhale during the jump
preparationSteps: Start in a standing position with feet shoulder-width apart
Ensure you have enough space around you
Keep your core engaged throughout the movement
Prepare mentally for an intense exercise

name: Jumping Lunge
description: Begin in a lunge position, then explosively jump upward switching legs in mid-air, landing softly with opposite leg forward, immediately lowering into the next lunge.
formTips: Keep torso upright throughout the movement
Land softly with control, absorbing impact through legs
Maintain 90-degree angles in both knees at bottom position
Use arms to help propel body upward during jump
commonMistakes: Landing heavily with straight legs
Allowing front knee to extend past toes
Letting torso lean too far forward
Not switching legs completely in mid-air
benefits: Builds explosive power in the lower body
breathingPattern: Exhale as you jump, inhale as you land and lower
preparationSteps: Start in a split stance with one foot forward, one back
Lower into a lunge position with knees at 90 degrees
Position arms for balance and momentum
Ensure adequate space around you

name: Skater Jumps
description: A lateral jumping exercise where you leap from side to side, landing on one foot while the other leg crosses behind, mimicking a speed skater's movement pattern.
formTips: Push off outside edge of foot when jumping laterally
Land softly with knee slightly bent to absorb impact
Touch hand or elbow to opposite knee for rotation
Maintain low center of gravity throughout
commonMistakes: Jumping too high instead of focusing on lateral distance
Landing with straight leg
Not allowing trailing leg to cross behind
Poor upper body coordination with lower body
benefits: Strengthens outer thighs and hip stabilizers
breathingPattern: Exhale as you push off for each jump, inhale as you land
preparationSteps: Start standing on one leg with soft knee
Position arms in ready position
Clear enough space for lateral movement (4-5 feet each side)
Begin with smaller jumps and gradually increase distance

name: Medicine Ball Slams
description: Lift a medicine ball overhead, then forcefully throw it to the ground using your core and upper body strength. Catch the ball on the bounce or pick it up and repeat.
formTips: Fully extend arms overhead before slamming
Use core and hips to generate power, not just arms
Slam ball directly downward in front of feet
Bend knees slightly to follow through and retrieve ball
commonMistakes: Using only arms instead of whole body
Not fully extending overhead before slam
Rounding back when picking up the ball
Throwing ball forward instead of straight down
benefits: Releases stress and tension through explosive movement
Builds power in the core and upper body
breathingPattern: Inhale as you lift the ball overhead, forcefully exhale during the slam
preparationSteps: Select appropriate weight medicine ball (6-20 lbs)
Stand with feet shoulder-width apart
Ensure adequate ceiling height for full extension
Clear space around you to avoid obstacles
